title: 1 Samuel Chapter 23 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Samuel chapter 23 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 23 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Samuel Chapter 23.

questions.question: Who were fighting against Keilah, according to 1 Samuel 23?
questions.correctAnswer: The Philistines
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 23:1 states that the Philistines fought against Keilah.

questions.question: What did David inquire of the LORD before going to Keilah?
options: Whether he should smite the Philistines
Whether he should build a city
questions.correctAnswer: Whether he should smite the Philistines
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 23:2, David asked the LORD if he should go and smite the Philistines.

questions.question: What was the response of David's men when he proposed going to Keilah?
options: They were afraid to go against the Philistines
They wanted to wait for reinforcements
questions.correctAnswer: They were afraid to go against the Philistines
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 23:3 says David's men expressed fear of fighting the Philistines at Keilah.

questions.question: What did the LORD say to David about attacking the Philistines at Keilah?
options: He would deliver the Philistines into David's hand
He advised David to avoid the battle
He told David to wait for Saul
He instructed David to fortify Keilah
questions.correctAnswer: He would deliver the Philistines into David's hand
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 23:4 states that the LORD told David to go down to Keilah because He would deliver the Philistines into his hand.

questions.question: What did David and his men do when they fought the Philistines at Keilah?
options: They smote them with great slaughter and took their cattle
questions.correctAnswer: They smote them with great slaughter and took their cattle
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 23:5 describes how David and his men fought the Philistines, smote them greatly, and brought away their cattle.

questions.question: Who fled to David at Keilah carrying an ephod?
questions.correctAnswer: Abiathar
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 23:6 tells that Abiathar, son of Ahimelech, fled to David at Keilah with an ephod.

questions.question: Why did Saul think David was delivered into his hand at Keilah?
options: Because David was shut in by entering a town with gates and bars
questions.correctAnswer: Because David was shut in by entering a town with gates and bars
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 23:7 shows Saul believed God delivered David into his hand since David was shut in a fortified town.

questions.question: What did Saul do after hearing David was at Keilah?
options: He called all the people to war to besiege Keilah
He sent a messenger to negotiate
questions.correctAnswer: He called all the people to war to besiege Keilah
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 23:8 states that Saul gathered his army to besiege Keilah to capture David.

questions.question: True or False: David used the ephod to inquire of the LORD about Saul's intentions at Keilah.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 23:9-11 explain how David asked Abiathar to bring the ephod to seek the LORD's guidance regarding Saul.

questions.question: According to the LORD, would the men of Keilah deliver David into Saul's hand?
questions.correctAnswer: Yes, they would deliver him
questions.explanation: Verses 11-12 state the LORD told David the men of Keilah would deliver him to Saul.

questions.question: What did David and his men do after learning the men of Keilah would deliver them up?
options: They arose and departed out of Keilah
questions.correctAnswer: They arose and departed out of Keilah
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 23:13 says David and his men left Keilah after hearing this, escaping Saul's grasp.

questions.question: Where did David abide after leaving Keilah?
options: In the land of the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: In the wilderness in strongholds
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 23:14 tells that David lived in the wilderness in strongholds after leaving Keilah.

questions.question: Who came to strengthen David's hand in the wilderness of Ziph?
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan, Saul's son
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 23:16 states that Jonathan came to David and strengthened his hand in God.

questions.question: True or False: Jonathan told David he would be king over Israel and Jonathan would be next to him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 23:17 records Jonathan encouraging David with the promise that he would be king and Jonathan his next.

questions.question: Who reported to Saul that David was hiding in the wood in the hill of Hachilah?
questions.correctAnswer: The Ziphites
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 23:19 tells that the Ziphites came to Saul and reported David's hiding place.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Samuel 23:28: 'Wherefore Saul returned from pursuing after David, and went against the ______: therefore they called that place Selahammahlekoth.'
questions.correctAnswer: Philistines
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 23:28 shows Saul turned to fight the Philistines, giving the place the name Selahammahlekoth.

medium.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 23 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Samuel Chapter 23 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does David's response to the threat against Keilah teach us about seeking God's guidance in difficult situations?
options: He immediately acted without asking God
He inquired of the LORD before acting
He relied on his own strength and wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: He inquired of the LORD before acting
questions.explanation: David sought God's direction twice before attacking the Philistines at Keilah, showing the importance of prayerful dependence on God (1 Samuel 23:2, 23:4, 23:9).

questions.question: What does the fear of David's men about fighting the Philistines at Keilah teach about human weakness and the need for faith?
options: They showed fear but still obeyed God's command
questions.correctAnswer: They showed fear but still obeyed God's command
questions.explanation: David's men expressed fear (1 Samuel 23:3) but David continued to seek God's will and led them according to God's promise of victory (1 Samuel 23:4-5), teaching faith over fear.

questions.question: How does David's interaction with Abiathar and the ephod demonstrate the importance of spiritual tools in discerning God's will?
options: David used the ephod to inquire of God
David relied only on his soldiers' advice
questions.correctAnswer: David used the ephod to inquire of God
questions.explanation: David asked Abiathar to bring the ephod (a priestly garment used for seeking God's guidance), highlighting the value of spiritual disciplines and seeking God's direction (1 Samuel 23:6, 23:9).

questions.question: What biblical principle about obedience can we learn from David's decision to leave Keilah after discovering the people would betray him?
options: Obedience to God includes trusting His warnings and acting accordingly
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God includes trusting His warnings and acting accordingly
questions.explanation: God informed David that the people of Keilah would deliver him to Saul, so David obeyed by leaving to protect his men, teaching us to trust God's warnings and act in faith for safety and obedience (1 Samuel 23:11-13).

questions.question: How does Jonathan’s support of David encourage believers to strengthen one another in faith during trials?
options: Jonathan strengthened David’s hand in God
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan strengthened David’s hand in God
questions.explanation: Jonathan came to encourage David and reminded him not to fear, showing the biblical value of fellowship and mutual encouragement in faith during difficult times (1 Samuel 23:16-17).

questions.question: What lesson about humility and trusting God is taught by David’s escape from Saul despite being surrounded?
options: David trusted in his own strength
David trusted God to deliver him
David blamed his men for failure
questions.correctAnswer: David trusted God to deliver him
questions.explanation: David fled when surrounded by Saul’s forces but ultimately God delivered him, teaching believers to rely on God's protection in trials and not self-reliance (1 Samuel 23:26, 23:14, 23:29).

questions.question: How does Saul’s reaction to the Ziphites’ betrayal of David illustrate the danger of misplaced trust compared to trusting God?
options: Saul trusted the Ziphites’ report and pursued David
Saul repented and stopped chasing David
questions.correctAnswer: Saul trusted the Ziphites’ report and pursued David
questions.explanation: Saul relied on human intelligence from the Ziphites to find David, rather than waiting on God’s timing, showing the risk of misplaced trust (1 Samuel 23:19-23).

questions.question: What does David’s continual inquiry of God about Saul’s plans teach about perseverance in prayer?
options: David repeatedly sought God's will through prayer
David ignored prayer and acted impulsively
David sought advice only from men
questions.correctAnswer: David repeatedly sought God's will through prayer
questions.explanation: David persistently inquired of the LORD about Saul's intentions (1 Samuel 23:2, 23:4, 23:9-12), demonstrating perseverance in prayer and dependence on God’s guidance.

questions.question: How does David’s protection of Keilah’s inhabitants after defeating the Philistines show biblical stewardship and concern for others?
options: David ignored the people after battle
David saved the inhabitants and took their cattle
questions.correctAnswer: David saved the inhabitants and took their cattle
questions.explanation: After defeating the Philistines, David rescued Keilah’s inhabitants and took the cattle, showing responsible stewardship and care for the community he protected (1 Samuel 23:5).

questions.question: A fellow believer is afraid to face a difficult challenge. Based on 1 Samuel 23, what truth about courage and faith would you share?
options: Fear is a sign of weak faith and should be ignored
Courage comes from trusting God’s promises and guidance
Avoid all challenges to stay safe
Rely only on your own strength
questions.correctAnswer: Courage comes from trusting God’s promises and guidance
questions.explanation: David's men were afraid, but David sought God's will and trusted His promise to deliver victory (1 Samuel 23:3-4, 23:5), teaching that faith in God gives true courage.

questions.question: What does the covenant between David and Jonathan reveal about biblical friendship and loyalty?
options: They made a covenant to betray Saul
They made a covenant before the LORD to support each other
Their friendship was based on convenience
questions.correctAnswer: They made a covenant before the LORD to support each other
questions.explanation: David and Jonathan's covenant (1 Samuel 23:18) shows the importance of godly friendship, loyalty, and mutual spiritual support grounded in a commitment before God.

questions.question: How does David’s staying in wilderness strongholds illustrate practical wisdom and trust in God during persecution?
options: David used safe places to protect his life while trusting God
questions.correctAnswer: David used safe places to protect his life while trusting God
questions.explanation: David lived in wilderness strongholds for safety while trusting God to deliver him, showing a balance of wise action and faith (1 Samuel 23:14, 23:29).

questions.question: True or False: David was confident that the men of Keilah would protect him from Saul.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David asked God if the men of Keilah would deliver him to Saul, and the LORD said they would, so David did not trust them and left the city (1 Samuel 23:11-13).

questions.question: True or False: Saul stopped pursuing David immediately after David escaped from Keilah.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Saul stopped pursuing David only after a messenger informed him that the Philistines had invaded, forcing him to redirect his attention (1 Samuel 23:27-28).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: After Saul ceased pursuing David, David went to dwell in strongholds at ________.
questions.correctAnswer: Engedi
questions.explanation: After Saul returned to fight the Philistines, David went up and dwelt in strongholds at Engedi as a place of refuge (1 Samuel 23:29).

hard.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 23 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Samuel Chapter 23.

questions.question: What was David's reason for enquiring of the LORD before attacking the Philistines at Keilah?
options: To confirm if he should save Keilah
To seek forgiveness for past sins
To find out if Saul was nearby
questions.correctAnswer: To confirm if he should save Keilah
questions.explanation: David sought the LORD's guidance to determine if he should go and smite the Philistines to save Keilah (1 Samuel 23:2).

questions.question: In 1 Samuel 23, who fled to David bringing an ephod, signifying priestly support?
questions.correctAnswer: Abiathar the son of Ahimelech
questions.explanation: Abiathar fled to David with an ephod, indicating his role as a priest and spiritual advisor (1 Samuel 23:6).

questions.question: How did David confirm Saul's intentions to besiege Keilah?
options: By enquiring of the LORD through the ephod
By sending spies to Saul's camp
By negotiating with the elders of Keilah
questions.correctAnswer: By enquiring of the LORD through the ephod
questions.explanation: David used the ephod to enquire of the LORD about Saul's plans to come to Keilah and destroy it (1 Samuel 23:9-11).

questions.question: What did the LORD reveal to David about the men of Keilah regarding Saul's pursuit?
options: They would deliver David and his men to Saul
They would protect David from Saul
questions.correctAnswer: They would deliver David and his men to Saul
questions.explanation: The LORD informed David that the men of Keilah would deliver him and his men into Saul's hand (1 Samuel 23:12).

questions.question: Where did David go after escaping from Keilah, according to 1 Samuel 23?
questions.correctAnswer: To the wilderness of Ziph
questions.explanation: David and his men fled to the wilderness of Ziph and stayed in strongholds there (1 Samuel 23:14).

questions.question: What was the significance of Jonathan's visit to David in the wilderness of Ziph?
options: He strengthened David's hand in God and confirmed David's future kingship
He brought David food and supplies
He warned David to flee to another country
He urged David to surrender to Saul
questions.correctAnswer: He strengthened David's hand in God and confirmed David's future kingship
questions.explanation: Jonathan encouraged David not to fear Saul, affirming David would be king and Jonathan would be next to him (1 Samuel 23:16-17).

questions.question: What covenant did David and Jonathan make before the LORD?
options: A covenant of mutual loyalty and support
A covenant to divide the kingdom
A covenant to unite with the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: A covenant of mutual loyalty and support
questions.explanation: David and Jonathan made a covenant before the LORD to support each other, demonstrating deep loyalty (1 Samuel 23:18).

questions.question: Who betrayed David's location to Saul, leading to Saul's pursuit?
questions.correctAnswer: The Ziphites
questions.explanation: The Ziphites informed Saul of David's hiding place and offered to deliver him into Saul's hand (1 Samuel 23:19-20).

questions.question: What tactic did Saul instruct the Ziphites to use in order to capture David?
options: To carefully scout all lurking places and report back
To attack David immediately without delay
questions.correctAnswer: To carefully scout all lurking places and report back
questions.explanation: Saul told the Ziphites to observe all places where David hid and report back with certainty (1 Samuel 23:22-23).

questions.question: What event forced Saul to abandon his pursuit of David in the wilderness of Maon?
options: The invasion of the Philistines into the land
questions.correctAnswer: The invasion of the Philistines into the land
questions.explanation: A messenger informed Saul that the Philistines had invaded, causing him to turn back and face them (1 Samuel 23:27-28).

questions.question: Where did David dwell after Saul ceased pursuing him, according to 1 Samuel 23?
options: In the hill country of Ephraim
questions.correctAnswer: In strongholds at Engedi
questions.explanation: After Saul stopped chasing him, David went up and dwelt in strongholds at Engedi (1 Samuel 23:29).

questions.question: True or False: David's men were confident and fearless about going to Keilah to fight the Philistines.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David's men expressed fear about fighting the Philistines at Keilah, showing their apprehension (1 Samuel 23:3).

questions.question: What is the significance of David retrieving cattle from the Philistines after the battle at Keilah?
options: It symbolized restoring what was stolen and showcased victory
It was a ransom payment for captives
It was a sacrifice to the LORD
It was a tribute to Saul
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolized restoring what was stolen and showcased victory
questions.explanation: David's men took away the cattle the Philistines had robbed, demonstrating deliverance and restoration for Keilah (1 Samuel 23:5).

questions.question: How does the ephod's presence in this chapter relate to priestly mediation in Israel's history?
options: It served as a means for David to seek divine guidance from the LORD
It was used as a weapon against the Philistines
It was a royal garment for kingship
questions.correctAnswer: It served as a means for David to seek divine guidance from the LORD
questions.explanation: The ephod was a priestly garment used by Abiathar to help David enquire of God, continuing the tradition of priestly mediation (1 Samuel 23:6,9).

questions.question: What theme in this chapter foreshadows David’s eventual kingship over Israel?
options: Jonathan’s assurance that David will be king and Jonathan next to him
Saul’s pursuit and failure to capture David
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan’s assurance that David will be king and Jonathan next to him
questions.explanation: Jonathan’s words to David affirm his future kingship, foreshadowing the Davidic dynasty (1 Samuel 23:17).

questions.question: How does the involvement of the Ziphites in betraying David reflect the political complexities in ancient Judah?
options: It shows local groups shifting allegiance to curry favor with Saul
It reflects a united front against David
It demonstrates Philistine influence over Judah
questions.correctAnswer: It shows local groups shifting allegiance to curry favor with Saul
questions.explanation: The Ziphites’ betrayal reveals internal divisions and political maneuvering as they sought to gain favor with King Saul (1 Samuel 23:19-20).

theological.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 23 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Samuel Chapter 23 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does David do first when he hears that the Philistines are attacking Keilah?
options: He inquires of the LORD whether he should attack the Philistines
He immediately gathers his men and attacks
He flees to the wilderness to avoid conflict
He sends messengers to Saul for help
questions.correctAnswer: He inquires of the LORD whether he should attack the Philistines
questions.explanation: David's first response is to seek divine guidance before acting, demonstrating reliance on God’s direction (1 Samuel 23:2). This aligns with biblical teaching about seeking God's will (Proverbs 3:5-6; James 1:5; Psalm 37:5; Isaiah 30:21).

questions.question: How does God assure David about the battle against the Philistines at Keilah?
options: God promises to deliver the Philistines into David's hand
God tells David to avoid the battle
God says the Philistines will win
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to deliver the Philistines into David's hand
questions.explanation: God assures David of victory, showing His sovereignty and faithfulness to His people (1 Samuel 23:4). This reflects God's providential care (Exodus 14:14; Deuteronomy 20:4; Romans 8:31; Psalm 44:3).

questions.question: What was the reaction of David's men to the prospect of fighting the Philistines at Keilah?
options: They expressed fear about facing the Philistine armies
They were eager and confident to fight
They suggested fleeing to another city
questions.correctAnswer: They expressed fear about facing the Philistine armies
questions.explanation: David's men displayed human fear despite God's promise, illustrating the tension between faith and human frailty (1 Samuel 23:3). Scripture encourages believers to trust God in fear (Psalm 56:3; Isaiah 41:10; Hebrews 13:6; 2 Timothy 1:7).

questions.question: What role does Abiathar the priest play when he comes to David at Keilah?
options: He brings the ephod to help David inquire of God
He commands the army to fight
questions.correctAnswer: He brings the ephod to help David inquire of God
questions.explanation: Abiathar's bringing of the ephod facilitates divine communication, highlighting the priestly function in mediating God's will (1 Samuel 23:6,9). This corresponds with the Old Testament priestly role (Exodus 28:30; Leviticus 8:8; Hebrews 7:23-25; 1 Timothy 2:5).

questions.question: Why does Saul believe David is trapped in Keilah?
options: Because Keilah is a fortified city with gates and bars
Because David has no men with him
Because Saul has spies inside the city
questions.correctAnswer: Because Keilah is a fortified city with gates and bars
questions.explanation: Saul assumes David cannot escape a fortified city, showing a misunderstanding of God's providential protection (1 Samuel 23:7). Scripture shows God’s power over human plans (Psalm 37:12-13; Jeremiah 17:14; Proverbs 21:30; Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What does David do to find out if the men of Keilah will betray him to Saul?
options: He inquires of the LORD using the ephod
He sends spies to the city
He confronts the people of Keilah directly
He hides and waits for Saul
questions.correctAnswer: He inquires of the LORD using the ephod
questions.explanation: David seeks God's guidance to discern human intentions, emphasizing reliance on divine wisdom over human judgment (1 Samuel 23:9-12). This reflects biblical trust in God's knowledge of hearts (1 Chronicles 28:9; Jeremiah 17:10; Hebrews 4:13; Proverbs 3:5-6).

questions.question: According to God's revelation, what will the men of Keilah do concerning David?
options: They will deliver David and his men into Saul's hand
They will protect David against Saul
questions.correctAnswer: They will deliver David and his men into Saul's hand
questions.explanation: God reveals the impending betrayal, teaching that divine omniscience includes foreknowledge of human sin (1 Samuel 23:12). This is consistent with biblical themes of God’s knowledge of human hearts and human sinfulness (Jeremiah 11:20; Psalm 44:20-21; Romans 3:23; Hebrews 4:13).

questions.question: What action does David take after learning the men of Keilah will betray him?
options: He and his men depart from Keilah
He decides to fight to the death
He hides within the city walls
questions.correctAnswer: He and his men depart from Keilah
questions.explanation: David responds prudently to God's guidance by fleeing, illustrating obedience to God's will for preservation (1 Samuel 23:13). This corresponds to biblical examples of wise retreat (Genesis 12:10; Exodus 1:17-21; Matthew 10:23; Acts 9:25).

questions.question: What does the covenant between David and Jonathan signify in the chapter?
options: A mutual commitment to support and protect each other under God's witness
A plan to overthrow the Philistines together
questions.correctAnswer: A mutual commitment to support and protect each other under God's witness
questions.explanation: The covenant exemplifies godly friendship and loyalty under divine authority (1 Samuel 23:18). Covenants in Scripture signify solemn vows before God (Genesis 21:27-32; Ruth 1:16-17; Proverbs 17:17; Ecclesiastes 4:9-12).

questions.question: Who assists Saul by informing him about David's whereabouts in the wilderness?
questions.correctAnswer: The Ziphites
questions.explanation: The Ziphites betray David by informing Saul, illustrating human treachery and the complexities of political alliances (1 Samuel 23:19-20). This is consistent with biblical accounts of betrayal (Genesis 37:18-28; Judges 9:22; Matthew 26:14-16; John 13:21-27).

questions.question: What reason does Saul give for blessing the Ziphites who inform him about David?
options: He says they have compassion on him
He says they are his loyal soldiers
He says they are wise counselors
He says they are godly men
questions.correctAnswer: He says they have compassion on him
questions.explanation: Saul perceives their betrayal as an act of compassion toward himself, revealing his perspective of David as an enemy (1 Samuel 23:21). This reflects biblical themes of mercy and compassion sometimes being misapplied (Luke 6:36; Romans 12:20-21; Proverbs 3:3-4; Matthew 5:7).

questions.question: How does David respond strategically when Saul and his men seek him in the wilderness of Maon?
options: He quickly moves to escape to avoid capture
He hides in a cave and waits
questions.correctAnswer: He quickly moves to escape to avoid capture
questions.explanation: David’s haste to evade Saul exemplifies wise stewardship of his life under God’s providence (1 Samuel 23:26). Scripture teaches prudence in danger (Proverbs 22:3; Ecclesiastes 9:18; Matthew 10:16; 1 Corinthians 9:26).

questions.question: What causes Saul to abandon his pursuit of David and return to fight the Philistines?
options: A messenger informs him that the Philistines have invaded the land
A plague breaks out among Saul’s men
questions.correctAnswer: A messenger informs him that the Philistines have invaded the land
questions.explanation: Saul’s shift in focus shows the priority of national defense over personal vendetta, reflecting God’s providential overruling of human affairs (1 Samuel 23:27-28). This aligns with biblical themes of God’s control over earthly events (Exodus 14:13-14; 1 Chronicles 21:1-15; Daniel 2:21; Romans 13:1).

questions.question: Where does David go after escaping Saul's pursuit in the wilderness?
options: He dwells in strongholds at Engedi
He goes to the city of Jerusalem
He hides in the Philistine territory
questions.correctAnswer: He dwells in strongholds at Engedi
questions.explanation: David’s retreat to the strongholds of Engedi demonstrates reliance on God’s protection and preparation for his future kingship (1 Samuel 23:29). This fits the biblical motif of God providing refuge (Psalm 91:1-2; Isaiah 16:3; Luke 4:8; Hebrews 6:18).

questions.question: What theological truth is highlighted by God’s repeated communication to David through the ephod and prophecy in this chapter?
options: God sovereignly directs the affairs of His people and reveals His will
God is silent and indifferent to human affairs
God punishes David for his doubts
God only speaks through dreams in this era
questions.correctAnswer: God sovereignly directs the affairs of His people and reveals His will
questions.explanation: The chapter underscores God’s active guidance and providence in human history through prophetic means (1 Samuel 23:2,4,9-12). This matches biblical teaching on God’s sovereignty and revelation (Isaiah 46:9-10; Psalm 32:8; John 16:13; Hebrews 1:1-2).

questions.question: What messianic theme is reflected in Jonathan's encouragement to David about his future?
options: David will be king over Israel, and Jonathan will be second to him
David will be a priest forever
David will defeat the Philistines and establish peace immediately
Jonathan will become king instead of David
questions.correctAnswer: David will be king over Israel, and Jonathan will be second to him
questions.explanation: Jonathan’s words acknowledge God’s sovereign plan for David’s kingship, foreshadowing the messianic line from David (1 Samuel 23:17). This relates to the Davidic covenant and Christ’s kingship (2 Samuel 7:12-16; Luke 1:32-33; Acts 2:30-31; Revelation 19:16).

questions.question: What does David’s repeated seeking of God’s guidance teach about the nature of true leadership in the biblical narrative?
options: True leadership depends on dependence on God’s wisdom and direction
Leadership is based solely on human strength and strategy
Leaders should act independently to demonstrate power
Leadership is primarily about political alliances
questions.correctAnswer: True leadership depends on dependence on God’s wisdom and direction
questions.explanation: David’s example models that godly leadership is rooted in submission to God’s will and guidance (1 Samuel 23:2,4,9). This principle is consistent with biblical instruction on leadership (Proverbs 11:14; James 1:5; Psalm 78:72; 1 Timothy 3:1-7).
